Posts.Content: Oct 20, 2011 08:53AM 4everhopeful wrote: Joanne,  ringing that bell doesn't necessarily mean than your treatment is done for good, it means that you have made it through this part of your journey.  We too have a bell at the Mississauga Cancer Centre where I go.  I did ring the bell when I did my very first round of chemo back in 2006 and boy did I ring that bell!!!!  I too had to go back for a bone treatment every 4 weeks.  I was in remission for 5 years.  January of this year, unfortunately I had to do chemo again, and after 6 months of it, I did not ring the bell and I felt my treatment was not over, as sure enough, it wasn't. Still doing chemo and if and when I'm done with this round, I will ring that bell loud and clear.  It's your own personal preference if you want to ring that bell or not, but I say GO FOR IT!  It's one hurdle over and done with!  Good Luck!  xoxo  Helen
Posts.Title: Should I ring the bell? Joanne_L susan_02143

Posts.Content: Nov 1, 2011 10:19AM 4everhopeful wrote: Becky, I too have 3 liver mets which were discovered in Jan of this year.  I did 18 Taxol treatments.  I have to say, the only se I had was muscle spasms.  Didn't have that " 3rd horrible day" that some people have.  However, I did lose ALL of my facial/body hair 3 weeks into treatment.  I worked full time throughout my treatment.  Good Luck with your treatment! Helen
Posts.Title: Info on Taxol rkt Heidi_Norway

Posts.Content: Sep 28, 2011 07:50AM 4everhopeful wrote: Celebrate EVERY CANCERVERSARY!!!!!  Always think positive thoughts, especially on scan day!  If it does show progression...so be it...you will fight it!  Good Luck on your results.  Friday will be my 6TH YEAR STAGE IV CANCERVERSARY and even though my last scan in January showed progression and I've been doing chemo everyweek, since then, I still think positive thoughts.  I will continue to fight this disease no matter what.  Keep up the fight!
Posts.Title: 3 yrs lovinmomma Reneepals

Posts.Content: Oct 6, 2010 11:25AM - edited Aug 20, 2013 05:53AM by 4everhopeful KSkier, Being diagnosed with stage 4 five years ago, and being told that I would probably die within a year or so ( as statistics show ), I celebrate each & ever day I wake up. Throwing my own party and having all the ones I love and who support me was not "tacky".  Totally different from throwing my own bridal shower.  I posted this celebration on here to give any of the ladies on here HOPE.  Not everyone with this terrible diagnosis has a strong positive mind.  I do and have from the beginning and  said that I would beat this " statistics bull S ".   From your post, I get the feeling that you do not have a positive outlook on your disease.  I do not think of my 5 years as using up my limited years.  I hope & pray each and every day that I live to see tomorrow.  I will continue to celebrate!

Posts.Content: Apr 6, 2010 08:58AM 4everhopeful wrote: Mags, I have mets to my spine from top to bottom and one spot on my hip.  I have had this for 5 years now.  I was on Femara for almost 4 years, and just switched to Aromasine as the hip met was just discovered in Feb/10.  I have ALOT of stiffness, especially first thing in the morning.  Its a side effect of the Femara/Aromasin.  If I sit for a long time, my legs get very stiff.  I also do an iv treatment once/month called Pamidtronate for the bones, which also gives me alot of stiffness.  You really have to not overdue it....if I do, my pain and stiffness is worse.  Helen
Posts.Title: stiffness assoicated with spinal mets mags123 ibcmets

Posts.Title: Poll - How old were you when dx with BC Times3 Minetta57

Posts.Content: Mar 16, 2010 05:26PM 4everhopeful wrote: Frankie, I was diagnosed with Stage IV with bone mets back in Sept 2006.  I was not given the size of my bone mets, because it is very hard for them to measure because of the bone tissue.  I too did not have any pain where bone mets were present, until after my chemo & radiation.  This is normal.  Maybe your oncologist is waiting to do another scan after all your chemo is finished.  If he does not order a scan in the near future, I would definitely demand to have one because if that is cancer on your rib area, they can do radiation to stop any growth.  I'm sure you will start hormone treatment soon - tamoxifin or Fermara.  This will also control bone mets. Good luck and stay positive.
Posts.Title: stage IV breast to bone mets ejnova reesie

Posts.Content: Mar 15, 2010 01:45PM 4everhopeful wrote: ejnova, I was diagnosed in Sept 2005 with Stage 4 w/bone mets to my spine.  I started taking Fermara and pamidtronate ( iv) once a month for the bone mets.  There were 2 new hot spots on the spine & hip area in Oct 2009, so dr. took me off Fermara, and now I take Aromasin also with the pamidtronate.  Also did many rounds of radiation.  Never had any pain in the bones indicating that the cancer was present.  Routine bone/ct scans picked this up.  My cancer is well controlled.  Good luck!
Posts.Title: stage IV breast to bone mets ejnova reesie

Posts.Content: Jun 29, 2011 01:59PM 4everhopeful wrote: Deborah, I have had bones mets from the get-go.  The oncologist I had when I was first diagnosed told me I would only live for 2 years....it will be 6 Years on Sept 1st.  Needless to say, I found myself a new oncologist immediately after she told me that.  My bone mets are under control and causing me no pain.

Posts.Title: Long Term Survivor with Active Mets 15andmore 15andmore

Posts.Content: Sep 17, 2010 09:33AM 4everhopeful wrote: Hi and welcome to the " Survivors Club".  Don't read statistics...only a number.  I'm coming up on my " 5 years " mark on Sept 30th and I feel great.  I have alot of bone mets and very little pain. I just take Motrin if I feel any pain coming on which is not very often.  I am on Xeloda ( oral chemo pill ) 3500mg/day..2 weeks on & 2 weeks off.  Been taking this now for 6 months.  Never felt greater! If you need any more inspiration than what we give you on here....read this article...17 years Survivor of Stage lV.....she sure is a true inspiration to me.   http://www.nytimes.com/2010/04/27/health/27case.html?_r=1 Good Luck with your treatment and ALWAYS THINK POSITIVE THOUGHTS!  Hugs!
Posts.Title: Newbie HERE welela52 Lowrider54

Posts.Content: Apr 19, 2011 10:57AM 4everhopeful wrote: luphy2006, I was diagnosed 5 1/2 YEARS AGO with Stage IV BC, with bone mets from the top of my spine to the bottom.  I had mastectomy, chemo & rads.  My bones mets have been pretty well controlled, with the odd zap last year.  Don't get discouraged about other people losing their battle, you have to keep a positive mind and fight with all your might!!!  There are woman on this site that were diagnosed 18 years ago with bone mets.  Keep up the fight!
